Package counter

A demonstration of concurrent processes in Java.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    ThreadSet<T extends java.lang.Thread>
    A thread set is a set of Threads which provides a facility for running all the threads in the set concurrently.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AbstractCounter
    A simple, potentially shared concurrent, counter class which can print a trace of its behaviour.
    Counter
    A simple, potentially shared concurrent, counter class which can print a trace of its behaviour.
    Main
    A demonstration of the use and behaviour of Counters and ThreadSets.
    ThreadHashSet<T extends java.lang.Thread>
    An implementation of thread sets.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    CounterException
    Exception class for counters.

Package counter Description

A demonstration of concurrent processes in Java. A AbstractCounter class is defined. A counter is an object that counts from an initial value to (or just past) a final value. Counters are defined as a subclass of Thread, so counters can be run concurrently. The internal value of counters is shared between all counters, so concurrent counters will "compete" to change the shared counter value.

The ThreadSet interface extends Set to sets of Thread, and adds a startSet() method that will start all of the threads in the thread set, and a joinSet() method that will wait for all of the threads to terminate. An implementation of this interface is provided in ThreadHashSet.

A demonstration of a possible use of these classes is provided in this package's Main class. For a visual demonstration please try the ui package's Main main class.

Note: The AbstractCounter and ThreadHashSet classes are currently incomplete.

Version:
January 2020
Author:
Hugh Osborne
